author: .paulharris
content: keymanager-api has that capability under certain conditions, but not of a running key... are you looking at this in the concept of moving keys?

author: .paulharris
content:
https://ethereum.github.io/keymanager-APIs/#/Local%20Key%20Manager
It's basically within the workflow of removing a key, so that you can safely add it elsewhere

author: baysa.g
content: Yes, trying to find out how to move the keys safely

author: baysa.g
content: The keys should be imported safely elsewhere, If the output of ‘DELETE’ method added into ‘POST’ method?

author: .paulharris
content: pretty much, the slashing protection file is the content of 'slashing_protection', so when you call delete and get that data, save it... if you dont - just call delete again on the deleted key and most implementations should give you the slashing data again (that's how its specified)

author: .paulharris
content:
then you can take that `slashing_protection` field and add it to the post method ... as a 1-off key its fairly simple but if adding/removing multiple and combinations etc, you potentially want to merge / split slashing_protection data (adding more keys etc)
generally i delete one and move all that data when im playing with that, keeps it fairly logical and easy to trace out

author: .paulharris
content: i guess to be less ambiguous, if moving 1 key, then the `slashing_protection` from the delete becomes the `slashing_protection` for the POST, but the POST does need more information like the actual keystore file and password, which is not output from the delete...

author: .paulharris
content: that `slashing_protection` data is the standard interchange format that all clients support to allow easy import/export of slashing data... that's why it's escaped json
